Dr. Mario Maruthur

MD

Dr. Maruthur is a Fellowship-trained and Board-Certified Mohs Micrographic surgeon and Board-Certified Dermatologist that focuses exclusively on skin cancer treatment. While his father was born in Kerala, India, and his mother was from Chicago, IL, he was born and raised in Hot Springs, Arkansas, where his father practiced medicine as an endocrinologist specializing in diabetes. After graduating as the valedictorian of his high school class, he attended Rhodes College in Memphis, TN, where he obtained a Bachelor of Science degree in Biology...keep reading[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type="1_3" module_class="team-member" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" border_radii="on|10px|10px|10px|10px" global_colors_info="{}"][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Barbie.jpg" alt="Barbie" title_text="Barbie" force_fullwidth="on" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" custom_margin="0px||0px||false|false" custom_padding="0px||0px||false|false" border_radii="off|10px|10px||" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text module_class="pa-toggle-text" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="3d1935f0-c622-48ce-824e-be21cacd454f" link_text_color="#0B61C7" header_4_text_color="#0B61C7" custom_padding="20px|20px|0px|20px|false|true" header_3_font_size_tablet="" header_3_font_size_phone="20px" header_3_font_size_last_edited="on|phone" locked="off" global_colors_info="{%22gcid-3f7cd2dc-b68c-4cc5-803f-18348add3227%22:%91%22link_text_color__hover%22,%22link_text_color__hover%22%93,%22gcid-67ca45d1-e275-42f7-b775-97f0494dc78c%22:%91%22link_text_color%22%93}" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD"]

Shannon Nix

Front Desk Coordinator Oxford

Shannon is from the Gadsden area and has been working in the medical field for over 25 years. She has experience working with various specialty groups, including neurology, hospitalists, women's health, and orthopedics. In her free time, Shannon enjoys antiquing, painting, and spending time with her kids. Christina Thomson

Front Desk Receptionist

Christina was born and raised in Gadsden Al, and spent 18 years in Florida. She has seven years of experience in the front office medical industry. Her hobbies include having fun with her nine grandchildren and her orange bobtail kitty. She enjoys any kind of seafood and is a big sushi lover.

Receptionist

Pamela Owen

Medical/Surgical Assistant

Pamela hails from Pell City AL. She Graduated from Pell City High School in 2003. She’s worked in various fields within the medical field including cardiology, peds, and dermatology for 18 years. Pamela is an avid self-taught crafter and tumbler maker. She enjoys spending time with her husband of 14 blissful years, and their dog Roxie.

Amie Golightly, LPN

Histotechnician

Amie is a Licensed Practical Nurse and Mohs Histotechnician. She joined the practice in 2017 after her husband retired from the Marine Corps. She lives in Springville with her husband and three children.

Shundra Sawyer

Medical Assistant

Shundra grew up in Gadsden, AL, graduating from Gadsden High School. She then attended Gadsden State Community College. Shundra has 25 years of experience as a medical assistant. Shundra enjoys spending time with her family. She and her husband Joseph have been married for 22 years. They have two children, Alicia and Joseph Jr., with the recent addition of their sweet grandson Major. Shundra's favorite food is seafood.

Jessica Payton

Medical Assistant

Raised in Springville, AL. Jessica enjoys spending time with her husband and 2 children: Coven and Gibson. She loves watching football and Nascar and spending time outdoors. Jessica has 3 dogs: Nelson, Yeti and Mario and 3 cats Priscilla, Tom and Sylvester.

Our Approach to Medical Care

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align_tablet="left" align_phone="center" align_last_edited="on|phone" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" global_colors_info="{}"]

Southern Skies Dermatology and Surgery is dedicated to diagnosing and treating skin cancer at our Birmingham/Trussville, Pell City, and Gadsden dermatology and surgery clinics. Our philosophy is that we are here to help, and we do that best by focusing on our area of expertise.

We believe your skin health is vital to your well-being, and every individual should have access to personal and affordable care. We specialize in the detection and treatment of skin cancers, which is often a worrying diagnosis for patients. You’ll always be greeted with a smile and can expect friendly services from each of our staff members. We believe in staying in close communication with our patients before, during, and after their medical visits with follow-up calls and emails.

A priority in our practice is working to continually improve the patient experience. This means creating more appointment spots when our patient backlog gets long, staying aware of our visit wait times to keep them fast and convenient, and taking to heart the feedback that we receive from patients.  

We also understand that our patients have varied experiences with dermatologists, and embark on treatments that are complicated and stressful. Our staff does our best to alleviate your worries with understanding and patience. Our doctors and advanced practice providers (APPs) are encouraged to continually expand their knowledge so our patients across Alabama receive the latest evidence-based, high-quality medical care.

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

Whilst it's recommended to try and get these words in, don't sacrifice readability and the quality of the SEO title just to rank higher - people may not want to click on it if it doesn't read well.";s:10:"status_msg";s:50:"Your focus keyword(s) aren't used in the SEO title";}s:12:"title_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:99:"Your SEO title is 60 characters which is between the recommended best practice of 50-65 characters.";s:9:"more_info";s:712:"Your SEO title is the most important element because it is what users will see in search engine results. You'll want to make sure that you have your focus keywords in there, that it's a nice length, and that people will want to click on it. Best practices suggest keeping your titles between 50 and 65 characters including spaces, though in some cases 60 is the sweetspot. The length is important both for SEO ranking but also how your title will show up in search engines - long titles will be cut off visually and look bad. Unfortunately there isn't a rule book for SEO titles, just remember to make your title great for SEO but also (most importantly) readable and enticing for potential visitors to click on.";s:10:"status_msg";s:31:"Your SEO title is a good length";}s:17:"metadesc_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:159:"The focus keyword for this article appears in the SEO description which means it has a better chance of matching what your visitors will search for, brilliant!";s:9:"more_info";s:456:"It's considered good practice to try to include your focus keyword(s) in the SEO description of your pages, because this is what people looking for the article are likely searching for. The higher chance of a keyword match, the higher chance your article will be found higher up in search results. Remember this is your chance to give a potential visitor a quick peek into what's inside your article. If they like what they read they'll click on your link.";s:10:"status_msg";s:48:"The SEO description contains your focus keywords";}s:15:"metadesc_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:159:"Your SEO description is a good length. Having an SEO description that is either too long or too short can harm your chances of ranking highly for this article.";s:9:"more_info";s:505:"We recommend keeping your meta descriptions between 135 and 300 characters (including spaces). Doing so achieves a nice balance between populating your description with keywords to rank highly in search engines, and also keeping it to a readable length that won't be cut off in search engine results. Unfortunately there isn't a rule book for SEO meta descriptions, just remember to make your description great for SEO, but also (most importantly) readable and enticing for potential visitors to click on.";s:10:"status_msg";s:38:"Your meta description is a good length";}s:13:"slug_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:195:"Google does index your page URL. Using your focus keywords in the page slug can help your page rank as you have a higher chance of matching search terms. Try getting your focus keywords in there.";s:9:"more_info";s:403:"The page URL you use for this post will be visible in search engine results, so it's important to also include words that the searcher is looking for (your focus keywords). It's debatable whether keywords in the slug are of any real search engine ranking benefit. One could assume that because the slug does get indexed, the algorithm may favour slugs more closely aligned with the topic being searched.";s:10:"status_msg";s:52:"You haven't used your focus keywords in the page URL";}s:13:"keywords_used";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:144:"Focus keywords are intended to be unique so you're less likely to write duplicate content. So far all your focus keywords are unique, way to go!";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:309:"None of the images on this page have alt text containing your focus keyword. It’s recommended practice to have your topic keywords in a few of your images to further associate the article with the topic you’re writing about. Add your keyword to one or more of your images, but be careful not to overdo it.";s:9:"more_info";s:244:"Image alternative text attributes help search engines correctly index images, aid visually impaired readers, and the text is used in place of the image if it's unable to load. You should add alternative text for all images in your content.";s:10:"status_msg";s:57:"None of your image alt texts contain the focus keyword(s)";}s:14:"content_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:74:"Your content is longer than the recommend minimum of 300 words, excellent!";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:84:"The text contains 1285 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:183:"Currently your keyword density is 0.19% which is below the recommended 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:36:"Your keyword density is less than 1%";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:162:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You've already added 11 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:56:"You have 8 internal and 3 external links in your content";}s:13:"para_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:171:"You've included your focus keywords in the first paragraph of your content, which will help search engines and visitors quickly scope the topic of your article. Well done!";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your reader’s attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Don’t forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"The focus keyword appears in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:152:"You've used keywords in 2 of your subheadings which will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about, good work!";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:45:"Your focus keyword was found in 2 subheadings";}}}

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

“I’m very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.” 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

“Today was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.”

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:307:"11/11 images on this page have alt text with your keyword(s) which is too much. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:83:"The text contains 324 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. You've already added 6 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. “I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

“I’m very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.” 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

“Today was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.”

global_colors_info="{}"]

About Dr. Mario Maruthur

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align="center" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="{}"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.19.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" link_text_color="#0B61C7" global_colors_info="{}" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD"]

Dr. Maruthur is a fellowship-trained and Board-Certified Mohs Micrographic surgeon and Board-Certified Dermatologist that focuses exclusively on skin cancer treatment. 

While his father was born in Kerala, India, and his mother was from Chicago, IL, he was born and raised in Hot Springs, Arkansas, where his father practiced medicine as an endocrinologist specializing in diabetes. After graduating as the valedictorian of his high school class, he attended Rhodes College in Memphis, TN, where he obtained a Bachelor of Science degree in Biology. After college, he decided to become an entrepreneur. He started a successful freight transportation and logistics company, which he ran for eight years specializing in over-dimensional and expedited freight shipping. Realizing that his true calling was in serving others, he changed paths and went back to school to pursue a career in medicine.  

He attended medical school at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, where he graduated at the top of his class with a 4.0 GPA. After medical school, he completed a dermatology residency at Emory University in Atlanta. Following residency, he moved to Augusta, GA. He began to practice general dermatology as a faculty member of the Department of Dermatology at the Medical College of Georgia (now known as Augusta University). Desiring to focus exclusively on skin cancer treatment, he applied to and was accepted into a Mohs Micrographic and Dermatologic Oncology fellowship at the very prestigious Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York (Ranked #2 cancer hospital in the United States). Under the instruction of renowned skin cancer surgeons Dr. Kishwer Nehal, Erica Lee, Kira Minkis, and Anthony Rossi, he learned the Mohs micrographic surgical technique for skin cancer excision and plastic surgery reconstruction of complex skin cancer defects.  

Dr. Maruthur lives in Vestavia Hills, AL, with his wife Dr. Kristina Falkenstrom, an intensive care (ICU) physician, and their Husky/Shepherd puppy Luka. In his downtime, he likes to cook, play tennis and golf, manage software development projects, and explore the beautiful Alabama outdoors.

Our goal is to be easily accessible to our patients and educate them on any topics related to skin cancer, skin disease, or skin health, which is why we encourage you to contact us with any questions you have by filling out this form. Our front desk team monitors your responses daily and is happy to respond appropriately!

With a variety of experts on our medical staff, we often consult each other to give you the best answers and results. We’re happy to provide you with personalized answers, and consultations, and schedule an appointment with you when it is necessary.

So far all your focus keywords are unique, way to go!";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:83:"The text contains 708 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:183:"Currently your keyword density is 0.55% which is below the recommended 1-3%. You've already added 16 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. Well done!";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your reader’s attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Don’t forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"The focus keyword appears in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:243:"Using keywords in any of your subheadings (such as H2's or H3's) will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about. Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:55:"You haven't used your focus keywords in any subheadings";}}}

meta._wds_title: Dr. Mario Maruthur | Mohs Surgeon | Southern Skies Dermatology
meta._wds_metadesc: Dr. Maruthur is a fellowship-trained, board-certified Mohs surgeon that focuses on skin cancer treatment and plastic surgery reconstruction after skin cancer surgery.
meta._wds_trimmed_excerpt: Dr. Mario Maruthur Specializes in X at Location 1 and Location 3 Completed fellowship in Mohs Micrographic Surgery and Dermatologic Oncology at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York Worked with and taught by renowned skin cancer surgeons Dr. Kishwer Nehal, Erica Lee, Kira Minkis ...
meta._wds_focus-keywords: Mohs Surgeon Skin Cancer Dermatologist near me surgery board certified cancer treatment

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

“I’m very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.” 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}"]

“Today was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.”

Having an SEO description that is either too long or too short can harm your chances of ranking highly for this article.";s:9:"more_info";s:505:"We recommend keeping your meta descriptions between 135 and 300 characters (including spaces). Doing so achieves a nice balance between populating your description with keywords to rank highly in search engines, and also keeping it to a readable length that won't be cut off in search engine results. Unfortunately there isn't a rule book for SEO meta descriptions, just remember to make your description great for SEO, but also (most importantly) readable and enticing for potential visitors to click on.";s:10:"status_msg";s:38:"Your meta description is a good length";}s:13:"slug_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:181:"You've got your focus keywords in the page slug which can help your page rank as you have a higher chance of matching search terms, and Google does index your page URL, great stuff!";s:9:"more_info";s:403:"The page URL you use for this post will be visible in search engine results, so it's important to also include words that the searcher is looking for (your focus keywords). It's debatable whether keywords in the slug are of any real search engine ranking benefit. One could assume that because the slug does get indexed, the algorithm may favour slugs more closely aligned with the topic being searched.";s:10:"status_msg";s:46:"You've used your focus keyword in the page URL";}s:13:"keywords_used";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:148:"Focus keywords are intended to be unique so you're less likely to write duplicate content. Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:307:"17/17 images on this page have alt text with your keyword(s) which is too much. Whilst it’s great that you have image alternative text with your focus keyword(s), you can also get penalized for having too many keywords on a page. Try to include your keyword(s) in image alt texts only when it makes sense.";s:9:"more_info";s:244:"Image alternative text attributes help search engines correctly index images, aid visually impaired readers, and the text is used in place of the image if it's unable to load. You should add alternative text for all images in your content.";s:10:"status_msg";s:61:"Too many of your image alt texts contain the focus keyword(s)";}s:14:"content_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:74:"Your content is longer than the recommend minimum of 300 words, excellent!";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:83:"The text contains 339 words which is more than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. The recommended density is 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:33:"You haven't used any keywords yet";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:161:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You've already added 6 links, nice work!";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:56:"You have 6 internal and 0 external links in your content";}s:13:"para_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:171:"You've included your focus keywords in the first paragraph of your content, which will help search engines and visitors quickly scope the topic of your article. Well done!";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your reader’s attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Don’t forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"The focus keyword appears in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:152:"You've used keywords in 8 of your subheadings which will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about, good work!";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:45:"Your focus keyword was found in 8 subheadings";}}}

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

“I’m very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.” 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

“Today was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.”

About Dr. Malia Downing

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align="center" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" text_font_size="17px" link_text_color="#0B61C7" global_colors_info="%91%93" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

Dr. Downing was raised in Hawaii and received her undergraduate degree from the College of Saint Scholastica in Duluth, MN where she played collegiate soccer and graduated Summa Cum Laude. She was awarded her medical doctorate from the University of North Dakota, graduating second in her class. Upon completing medical school, she moved to Kansas City, KS where she did her medical internship and dermatology residency at the University of Kansas. Dr. Downing completed her fellowship training in Micrographic Surgery and Dermatologic Oncology and Cosmetic Dermatologic Surgery at Surgical Dermatology Group in Birmingham, AL where she received advanced training in the management of skin cancers and reconstructive techniques.

She was also a regular volunteer at the KC Health Center, providing dermatologic care to uninsured patients. She is a member of the American Academy of Dermatology, the American Society for Dermatologic Surgery, the American College of Mohs Surgery, and the Alpha Omega Alpha Medical Honor Society. In her free time, Dr. Downing enjoys scuba diving, spear fishing, hiking, skiing, working on her family's farm in Hawaii, and spending time with her husband, sons, and dogs.

Ask Dr. Malia Downing a Question

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" custom_margin="0px||0px||true|false" custom_padding="0px||0px||true|false" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

Our goal is to be easily accessible to our patients and educate them on any topics related to skin cancer, skin disease, or skin health, which is why we encourage you to contact us with any questions you have by filling out this form. Our front desk team monitors your responses daily and is happy to respond appropriately!

With a variety of experts on our medical staff, we often consult each other to give you the best answers and results. We’re happy to provide you with personalized answers, and consultations, and schedule an appointment with you when it is necessary.

Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. button_url_new_window="1" icon_color="1" use_rating="on" social_target="1" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" blank_color="#FFFFFF" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="{}"]

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" icon_color="1" use_rating="on" social_target="1" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="{}"]

“I’m very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.” 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" icon_color="1" use_rating="on" social_target="1" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="{}"]

“Today was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][/dica_divi_carousel][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section][et_pb_section fb_built="1" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" disabled_on="on|on|on" About Dr. Malia Downing

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image custom_padding="||30px||false|false" align_last_edited="on|phone" align="center" align_tablet="left" show_bottom_space="off" align_phone="center" src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" hover_enabled="0" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text module_class="big-heading" header_2_text_color="#E09900" header_2_text_align="left" text_text_color="#000000" custom_padding="0px||0px||false|false" header_2_font_size="50px" header_2_font_size_last_edited="on|phone" header_2_font_size_tablet="40px" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" custom_margin_last_edited="on|desktop" custom_margin="||20px||false|false" header_2_text_align_last_edited="on|desktop" header_2_text_align_tablet="left" header_2_text_align_phone="center" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_font_size="17px" text_line_height="33px" text_orientation_tablet="left" text_orientation_phone="center" text_orientation_last_edited="on|phone" _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" link_text_color="#0B61C7" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="%91%93" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD"]

Dr. Downing was raised in Hawaii and received her undergraduate degree from the College of Saint Scholastica in Duluth, MN where she played collegiate soccer and graduated Summa Cum Laude. She was awarded her medical doctorate from the University of North Dakota, graduating second in her class. Upon completing medical school, she moved to Kansas City, KS where she did her medical internship and dermatology residency at the University of Kansas. Dr. Downing completed her fellowship training in Micrographic Surgery and Dermatologic Oncology and Cosmetic Dermatologic Surgery at Surgical Dermatology Group in Birmingham, AL where she received advanced training in the management of skin cancers and reconstructive techniques.

She was also a regular volunteer at the KC Health Center, providing dermatologic care to uninsured patients. She is a member of the American Academy of Dermatology, the American Society for Dermatologic Surgery, the American College of Mohs Surgery, and the Alpha Omega Alpha Medical Honor Society. In her free time, Dr. Downing enjoys scuba diving, spear fishing, hiking, skiing, working on her family's farm in Hawaii, and spending time with her husband, sons, and dogs.

Our goal is to be easily accessible to our patients and educate them on any topics related to skin cancer, skin disease, or skin health, which is why we encourage you to contact us with any questions you have by filling out this form. Our front desk team monitors your responses daily and is happy to respond appropriately!

With a variety of experts on our medical staff, we often consult each other to give you the best answers and results. We’re happy to provide you with personalized answers, and consultations, and schedule an appointment with you when it is necessary.

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" use_rating="on" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" global_colors_info="{}" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

About Raven Omar, PA-C

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" align="center" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" link_text_color="#0B61C7" global_colors_info="%91%93" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

Raven Omar, PA-C has worked in Dermatology as a surgical physician assistant since 2024, assisting in Mohs procedures and post-mohs plastics reconstruction.

Raven was born and raised in Birmingham, AL. She attended Clay-Chalkville High School and graduated at the top of her class. She attended Samford University, where she played point guard for the women's basketball team from 2017-2021 and helped them to two championships. She obtained her Bachelor of Science degree in Health Sciences in 2021. She also obtained her Masters in Physician Assistant Studies in December of 2023 from Samford University, as well.

Raven enjoys spending time with friends and family, online shopping, and making people laugh. She has a passion for caring for people and serving others, and will always make it a priority to make sure her patient's leave with a smile!

Ask Raven a Question

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version="4.17.1" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" custom_margin="0px||0px||true|false" custom_padding="0px||0px||true|false" global_colors_info="%91%93" theme_builder_area="post_content"]

Our goal is to be easily accessible to our patients and educate them on any topics related to skin cancer, skin disease, or skin health, which is why we encourage you to contact us with any questions you have by filling out this form. Our front desk team monitors your responses daily and is happy to respond appropriately!

With a variety of experts on our medical staff, we often consult each other to give you the best answers and results. We’re happy to provide you with personalized answers, and consultations, and schedule an appointment with you when it is necessary.

If they like what they read they'll click on your link.";s:10:"status_msg";s:48:"The SEO description contains your focus keywords";}s:15:"metadesc_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:132:"Your SEO description (or excerpt) is currently too short which means it has less of a chance ranking for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:505:"We recommend keeping your meta descriptions between 135 and 300 characters (including spaces). Doing so achieves a nice balance between populating your description with keywords to rank highly in search engines, and also keeping it to a readable length that won't be cut off in search engine results. Unfortunately there isn't a rule book for SEO meta descriptions, just remember to make your description great for SEO, but also (most importantly) readable and enticing for potential visitors to click on.";s:10:"status_msg";s:49:"Your meta description is less than 135 characters";}s:13:"slug_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:181:"You've got your focus keywords in the page slug which can help your page rank as you have a higher chance of matching search terms, and Google does index your page URL, great stuff!";s:9:"more_info";s:403:"The page URL you use for this post will be visible in search engine results, so it's important to also include words that the searcher is looking for (your focus keywords). It's debatable whether keywords in the slug are of any real search engine ranking benefit. One could assume that because the slug does get indexed, the algorithm may favour slugs more closely aligned with the topic being searched.";s:10:"status_msg";s:46:"You've used your focus keyword in the page URL";}s:13:"keywords_used";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:148:"Focus keywords are intended to be unique so you're less likely to write duplicate content. Consider changing the focus keywords to something unique.";s:9:"more_info";s:1153:" Whilst duplicate content isn't technically penalized it presents three rather niggly issues for search engines:

1. It's unclear which versions to include/exclude from their indexes.
2. They don't know whether to direct the link metrics (trust, authority, anchor text, link equity, etc.) to one page, or keep it separated between multiple versions.
3. The engine is unsure which version to rank for query results.

So whilst there's no direct penalty, if your content isn't unique then search engine algorithms could be filtering out your articles from their results. The easiest way to make sure this doesn't happen is to try and make each of your posts and pages as unique as possible, hence specifying different focus keywords for each article you write.

Note: If you happen to have two pages with the same content, it's important to tell search engines which one to show in search results using the Canonical URL feature. You can read more about this here. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:42:"You haven't used this focus keyword before";}s:16:"imgalts_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:378:"Images are a great addition to any piece of content and it’s highly recommended to have imagery on your pages. Consider adding a few images that relate to your body content to enhance the reading experience of your article. Where possible, it’s also a great opportunity to include your focus keyword(s) to further associate the article with the topic you’re writing about.";s:9:"more_info";s:244:"Image alternative text attributes help search engines correctly index images, aid visually impaired readers, and the text is used in place of the image if it's unable to load. You should add alternative text for all images in your content.";s:10:"status_msg";s:33:"You haven't added any images";}s:14:"content_length";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:189:"Unless your website is a photography blog it's generally a good idea to include content for your visitors to read, and also for Google to index. Something, anything, is better than nothing.";s:9:"more_info";s:798:"Content is ultimately the bread and butter of your SEO. Without words, your pages and posts will have a hard time ranking for the keywords you want them to. As a base for any article best practice suggests a minimum of 300 words, with 1000 being a good benchmark and 1600 being the optimal. Numerous studies have uncovered that longer content tends to perform better than shorter content, with pages having 1000 words or more performing best. Whilst optimizing your content for search engines is what we're going for here, a proven bi-product is that high quality long form articles also tend to get shared more on social platforms. With the increasing power of social media as a tool for traffic it's a nice flow on effect of writing those juicy high quality articles your readers are waiting for.";s:10:"status_msg";s:81:"The text contains 0 words which is less than the recommended minimum of 300 words";}s:15:"keyword_density";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:1;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:196:"Currently you haven't used any keywords in your content. The recommended density is 1-3%. A low keyword density means your content has less chance of ranking highly for your chosen focus keywords.";s:9:"more_info";s:728:"Keyword density is all about making sure your content is populated with enough keywords to give it a better chance of appearing higher in search results. One way of making sure people will be able to find our content is using particular focus keywords, and using them as much as naturally possible in our content. In doing this we are trying to match up the keywords that people are likely to use when searching for this article or page, so try to get into your visitors mind and picture them typing a search into Google. While we recommend aiming for 1-3% density, remember content is king and you don't want your article to end up sounding like a robot. Get creative and utilize the page title, image caption, and subheadings.";s:10:"status_msg";s:33:"You haven't used any keywords yet";}s:11:"links_count";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:202:"Internal links help search engines crawl your website, effectively pointing them to more pages to index on your website. You should consider adding at least one internal link to another related article.";s:9:"more_info";s:1261:" Internal links are important for linking together related content. Search engines will 'crawl' through your website, indexing pages and posts as they go. To help them discover all the juicy content your website has to offer, it's wise to make sure your content has internal links built in for bots to follow and index.

External links don't benefit your SEO by having them in your own content, but you'll want to try and get as many other websites linking to your articles and pages as possible. Search engines treat links to your website as a 'third party vote' in favour of your website - like a vote of confidence. Since they're the hardest form of 'validation' to get (another website has to endorse you!) search engines weight them heavily when considering page rank. For more info: https://moz.com/learn/seo/internal-link

Note: This check is only looking at the content your page is outputting and doesn't include your main navigation. Blogs with lots of posts will benefit the most from this method, as it aids Google in finding and indexing all of your content, not just the latest articles. ";s:10:"status_msg";s:64:"You haven't added any internal or external links in your content";}s:13:"para_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:169:"It's good practice to include your focus keywords in the first paragraph of your content so that search engines and visitors can quickly scope the topic of your article.";s:9:"more_info";s:541:"You should clearly formulate what your post is about in the first paragraph. In printed texts, a writer usually starts off with some kind of teaser, but there is no time for that if you are writing for the web. You only have seconds to gain your reader’s attention. Make sure the first paragraph tells the main message of your post. That way, you make it easy for your reader to figure out what your post is about. Doing this also tells Google what your post is about. Don’t forget to put your focus keyword in that first paragraph! ";s:10:"status_msg";s:78:"You haven't included the focus keywords in the first paragraph of your article";}s:20:"subheadings_keywords";a:5:{s:6:"status";b:0;s:7:"ignored";b:0;s:14:"recommendation";s:277:"Using subheadings in your content (such as H2's or H3's) will help both the user and search engines quickly figure out what your article is about. It also helps visually section your content which in turn is great user experience. We recommend you have at least one subheading.";s:9:"more_info";s:478:"When trying to rank for certain keywords, those keywords should be found in as many key places as possible. Given that you're writing about the topic it only makes sense that you mention it in at least one of your subheadings. Headings are important for users as they break up your content and help readers figure out what the text is about. Same goes for search engines. With that said, don't force keywords into all your titles - keep it natural, readable, and use moderation!";s:10:"status_msg";s:30:"You don't have any subheadings";}}}

“I was extremely pleased with my experience at Southern Skies. Dr. Mario and his NP, Adrienne, removed a large basal cell on the top of my lip. It was a very extensive procedure resulting in more than 40 external stitches. Within a month the scar was barely noticeable. Much care and thought were given to how and where to make the incisions. Taking into account my facial creases, wrinkles, etc., the scar is almost completely hidden. I recommend them highly!”

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Rebecca Long, Gadsden" button_url_new_window="1" icon_color="1" use_rating="on" social_target="1" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="{}"]

“I’m very pleased with the care and concern of this staff. Dr. M did a great job on my ear. The reconstruction looks wonderful. You have to look really close to tell anything was done. They are professionals, but they treat me like family.” 

[/dica_divi_carouselitem][dica_divi_carouselitem title="Michael Brown, Ohatchee" button_url_new_window="1" icon_color="1" use_rating="on" social_target="1" rating_alignment="center" rating_position="rating-top" rating_icon_size="41px" rating_color="#FFD700" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="default" header_level="h2" header_text_align="center" header_font_size="20px" body_text_align="center" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="{}"]

“Today was my doctor visit day at Southern Skies. I never want to go to the doctor, but I know how important it s for my health. I can say that Dr. Mario and his staff are very professional in their treatment. They make me feel secure with their treatment and knowledge.”

About Raven Omar, PA-C

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image custom_padding="||30px||false|false" align_last_edited="on|phone" align="center" align_tablet="left" show_bottom_space="off" align_phone="center" src="https://southernskiesdermatology.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Divider-small-new-yellow.png" title_text="Divider" _builder_version="4.17.4" _module_preset="04d09abd-7579-4b9c-808e-c7ad250d8198" hover_enabled="0" locked="off" global_colors_info="%91%93"][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text module_class="big-heading" header_2_text_color="#E09900" header_2_text_align="left" text_text_color="#000000" custom_padding="0px||0px||false|false" header_2_font_size="50px" header_2_font_size_last_edited="on|phone" header_2_font_size_tablet="40px" custom_padding_last_edited="on|tablet" custom_margin_last_edited="on|desktop" custom_margin="||20px||false|false" header_2_text_align_last_edited="on|desktop" header_2_text_align_tablet="left" header_2_text_align_phone="center" text_font="Roboto||||||||" text_font_size="20px" text_line_height="33px" text_orientation_tablet="left" text_orientation_phone="center" text_orientation_last_edited="on|phone" _builder_version="4.27.4" _module_preset="399dc1c6-5b92-4bd9-a1dd-0455d30e3551" link_text_color="#0B61C7" hover_enabled="0" global_colors_info="%91%93" link_text_color__hover_enabled="on|hover" link_text_color__hover="#007DBD"]

Raven Omar, PA-C has worked in Dermatology as a surgical physician assistant since 2024, assisting in Mohs procedures and post-mohs plastics reconstruction.

Raven was born and raised in Birmingham, AL. She attended Clay-Chalkville High School and graduated at the top of her class. She attended Samford University, where she played point guard for the women's basketball team from 2017-2021 and helped them to two championships. She obtained her Bachelor of Science degree in Health Sciences in 2021. She also obtained her Masters in Physician Assistant Studies in December of 2023 from Samford University, as well.

Raven enjoys spending time with friends and family, online shopping, and making people laugh. She has a passion for caring for people and serving others, and will always make it a priority to make sure her patient's leave with a smile!

Our goal is to be easily accessible to our patients and educate them on any topics related to skin cancer, skin disease, or skin health, which is why we encourage you to contact us with any questions you have by filling out this form. Our front desk team monitors your responses daily and is happy to respond appropriately!

With a variety of experts on our medical staff, we often consult each other to give you the best answers and results. We’re happy to provide you with personalized answers, and consultations, and schedule an appointment with you when it is necessary.
